home-desc: <0>You can also call 8-1-1 to talk to someone at HealthLink BC. They can:</0><1><0>Answer questions and provide advice for your specific situation</0><1>Offer help in different languages</1></1><2>Do not use this self-assessment to check symptoms for anyone under 2 years old. Contact your health care provider or 8-1-1 instead.</2><3>The information in this tool is based on expert guidance from the British Columbia Centre for Disease (BCCDC). It does not replace your health care provider's advice.</3>
home-children-desc: Children generally show COVID-19 symptoms differently than adults. For example, they may have milder symptoms, or they may show a change in energy level, appetite or behaviour.
home-children-link: Learn more about COVID-19 and children.
Cough: Cough (either new or worsening/exacerbation of chronic cough)
DownloadAppDescription: Read the latest BC Government COVID-19 health guidance and keep your BC vaccine card and Federal COVID-19 Travel Proofs in a single place
Loss of sense of smell or taste: Loss of sense of smell or taste
Q1: Are you experiencing any of the following?
Q1-1: Severe difficulty breathing (e.g., struggling to breathe or speaking in single words)
Q1-3: Having a very hard time waking up
Q2: Are you experiencing any of the following?
Q2-1: I cannot lie down because I'm having trouble breathing
Q2-2: I'm having trouble managing my chronic health conditions because of difficulty breathing
Q4: Have you received a new COVID-19 test result?
Q4-desc: If you have not entered it here before, enter the details of your last COVID-19 test.
Q4-help: Sharing your COVID-19 test results helps public health understand and respond to COVID-19.
Q4-Enter the details: Enter the details of your COVID-19 test.
Question: Question
ResultAsymptomaticNoTest: You do not need a COVID-19 test.
ResultAsymptomaticDescription: <0>Pay attention to how you're feeling.</0> If you start developing symptoms, you can re-take this self-assessment tool.
ResultAsymptomaticNotice1: If you have any questions, you can contact your health care provider or call 8-1-1 to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC
ResultSymptomaticNoTest: You do not need a COVID-19 test.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestDescription1: Testing is not recommended for adults and children with mild symptoms. Stay home until you feel well enough to resume your regular activities. Avoid high risk settings (e.g. long term care facilities) and individuals at higher risk for severe complications for 10 days after the start of your symptoms.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestDescription2: If you are uncertain and/or feel very sick, call 8-1-1 or contact your primary care provider.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice1: Note that sometimes symptoms may suddenly worsen and require urgent medical care.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice2: Pay attention to how you are feeling. If it becomes harder to breathe, you can’t drink anything or feel much worse, call 9-1-1 or go to your nearest emergency department.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice3: For more information on COVID-19 and how to stay safe, visit the <2>BCCDC website</2>.
ResultRapidTest: Stay home and away from others until you feel well enough to return to your regular activities and you no longer have a fever.
ResultRapidTestDescription1: You can get a rapid COVID-19 test if you'd like.
ResultRapidTestDescription2: Rapid antigen testing kits are free for everyone. Visit your local pharmacy and ask for your testing kit.
ResultRapidTestNotice: <0>Find more information</0> on getting a rapid antigen test kit.
ResultSymptomaticTest: Please get a COVID-19 test and self-isolate.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription1: A PCR test may be the preferred COVID-19 test. However, other test types can be used
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription2: <0>Find out where to get a test</0>. You need to <3>self-isolate</3> while you wait for your test result.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription4: <0>Find out it you may benefit from treatment.</0>
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription6: <0><0>If you test positive for COVID-19, are 18 years or older, and are not fully vaccinated</0>, self-isolate for at least 10 days from the day your symptoms started. You can stop isolating after 10 days as long as your fever has resolved without the use of fever-reducing medication, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, and your symptoms have improved.</0><1><0>If you test positive for COVID-19 and are fully vaccinated or are under 18 years old</0>, self-isolate for at least 5 days from the day your symptoms started. You can stop isolating after 5 days as long as your fever has resolved without the use of fever-reducing medication, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, and your symptoms have improved.</1><2>Fully vaccinated means you received both doses of a 2-dose series (e.g. AstraZeneca, Pfizer, or Moderna vaccine) or it has been more than 14 days since you received a single dose of a 1-dose series (e.g. Janssen/ Johnson and Johnson). </2><3><0>If you test negative for COVID-19</0>, stay home until you feel well enough to return to your regular activities.</3>
ResultSymptomaticTestNotice:
<0><0>Pay attention to how you're feeling. If your symptoms change, you should get health advice:<1><0>Contact your health care provider
OR <1>Call 8-1-1 to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC<2>Call 9-1-1 or visit an <2>Urgent and Primary Care Centreor emergency department right away if you start to feel very sick - for example, if it gets hard to breathe or you can't drink anything.
Result811: You should get health advice. Contact your health care provider or call 8-1-1 to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC.
Result811Notice: <0>Pay attention to how you’re feeling.</0> You should call 9-1-1 or visit an <3>Urgent and Primary Care Centre</3> emergency department right away if you start to feel worse – for example, if it gets hard to breathe or you can’t drink anything.
Result911: Your symptoms require emergency medical care. Call 9-1-1 or visit an Urgent and Primary Care Centre or emergency department right away.
Result911Description: These symptoms require emergency medical care. You should call <1>9-1-1 immediately</1>, or go directly to your nearest emergency department.
Tool description: Use this self-assessment tool to find out if you need a COVID-19 test. You can complete it for yourself or someone else.
Home alert: If you feel very sick or your symptoms are not improving, contact your health care provider
HWQ1: Are you an individual who is moderately to severely immunocompromised?
HWQ1-1: You’ve had an organ transplant and are taking anti-rejection medications
HWQ1-2: You are receiving treatment for cancer
HWQ1-3: You’ve had a bone marrow or stem cell transplant
HWQ1-4: You’ve been diagnosed with a moderate to severe primary immunodeficiency disorder
HWQ1-5: You have advanced or untreated HIV
HWQ1-6: You’ve been diagnosed with HIV and are not currently taking medications for it
HWQ1-7: You are on dialysis and/or have severe kidney disease
HWQ1-8: You are on active treatment with immunosuppressive therapies
HWQ2: Are you an individual who has any one of the following conditions?
HWQ2-2: You have severe COPD, asthma or another serious respiratory condition (e.g. on long-term home oxygen, are being assessed for a lung transplant, have severe pulmonary arterial hypertension, severe pulmonary fibrosis, or severe interstitial lung disease)
HWQ2-3: You’ve been diagnosed with a rare blood disorder or inborn error of metabolism
HWQ2-4: You’ve had a splenectomy or you have functional asplenia
HWQ2-5: You have diabetes and are being treated with insulin
HWQ2-6: You have a significant developmental disability
HWQ2-7: You have a condition or syndrome that causes muscle weakness around the lungs requiring the use of a ventilator or continuous bi-PAP
HWQ4: Do you self-identify as Indigenous (First Nations, Metis, and/or Inuit)?
HWQ5: Please select your COVID-19 vaccination status:
HWQ5-1: I am not vaccinated for COVID-19.
HWQ5-2: I have received 1 or 2 doses of a 2-dose series like Pfizer, Moderna, Novavax or AstraZeneca or have received 1 dose of a 1-dose series like Johnson & Johnson.
HWQ5-3: I am fully vaccinated (completed my vaccine series) and I have also received a booster dose.
HWQ6-1: I am 49 years old or younger.
HWQ6-3: I am 70 years old or older.
HWQ7-M: Do you have 3 or more chronic conditions?
HWQ7-desc: (e.g., obesity, diabetes, heart failure, stroke, or a neurological condition)
HWQ7-S: Do you have 1 or more chronic conditions?
